column1: In this course, students will do the research for and at the level of writing a publishable academic paper (i.e., law review article, case note or comment). The course will cover effective use of primary and secondary legal research sources in both print and electronic formats. Students will go beyond the basic research methods taught in the required Legal Research course and learn the research methods necessary to fully analyse and discuss a complicated legal issue. All students in the course will be required to complete all the components required to satisfy the Legal Academic Writing Requirement, including a final paper which shall be on a level equal to the ones that are publishable. This course is Mandatory for all students that wish to follow the International Law major and it will be offered at year 2.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/97503,2020,Legal Perspectives on the Governance of Migration and Diversity,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Schiller', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will provide students of the Master in the Governance of Migration and Diversity with an introduction into the legal dimension of migration and diversity governance. This includes global migration law (including the Global Compact on Migration) as well as a specific focus on EU migration and asylum law (including Free Movement, Schengen, Dublin and Return policies). Furthermore, the course devotes attention to diversity law, in particular in the area of human rights and minority protection. At the end of the course students will have knowledge of the most important legal principles and structures and understand the relevance of these for the governance of migration and diversity. Furthermore, students will be challenged to analyse concrete governance dilemmas by considering their legal dimension.

column2: • Introduction: a legal perspective on the governance of migration and diversity
• Basics of European migration and asylum law
• Essay in which students apply legal principles/structures to a concrete governance dilemma (40%).
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Study objectives. After this course, students will be able to

column2: • Identify the most important legal principles and structures in global and European migration law
• Identify the most important legal principles and structures in human rights law and minorities protection
• Understand the relevance and implications of these legal principles and structures for the governance of migration
• Apply legal principles and structures to concrete governance dilemmas.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92603,2020,Legal Psychology,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. EGC Rassin'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Legal psychology aims to apply scientific psychological knowledge to the legal arena, particularly to criminal procedure. Hence, legal psychologists seek to study the behaviour of police, districts attorney, defence lawyer, judge, and jury. These parties may also ask legal psychologists explicitly for assistance. By and large, legal psychologists study the evidence used in court. In this course, various pieces of evidence, such as, witness statements including identifications, and suspect statements will be reviewed.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The main goal of this course is to offer an introduction of legal psychology to the student. The following topics will be introduced during this course: Witness testimony, suspect testimony, lie detection. Besides these specific topics, it is important to gain insight in legal psychology as a discipline, and to appreciate the position of the psychologist in the criminal procedure.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Legal psychology is a new and upcoming field where science and the profession of psychology    is applied to questions and issues relating to law and the legal system. As a legal psychologist, you will be called upon to answer a broad range of difficult questions, such as, but not limited to:

column2: • Is there a relationship between the mental disorder of a suspect and their behavior during the crime?
• How big is the risk that someone will re-offend in the future?

column1: You will provide the judge with advice in criminal proceedings so the group of patients you'll work with will be diverse and demanding. They may have severe antisocial behavior and/or co- morbid mental disorders (such as schizophrenia combined with substance abuse disorders).

You will also need knowledge in the field of material law and legal procedures to be effective as an expert witness in court, for example being able to evaluate certain pieces of evidence. This means that you will need a very particular skillset.

This course will provide a small taste to the vast and wide world of legal psychology ranging from reliability of witness statements, the validity of confession evidence, interrogation techniques and avoiding professional biases. This is just the tip of the iceberg!

<body>During this course, the following topics will be dealt covered:

column2: • How to prevent bias with a Bayesian approach to evidence.

column1: The aims of the course are to give students knowledge regarding core questions of contemporary legal theory and to help them develop their own critical perspective on the enterprise of law.

The students are required to study central articles by contemporary legal theorists and examine their arguments together (i); students are required to prepare assignments on set topics (ii); the exam will test students’ knowledge by setting problems, related to the literature, that allow students to show their argumentative skill as well (iii).

column1: After this course students are able to:
1.  analyze problems related to the concept of law from different perspectives and develop arguments based on different theories about the concept of law;
2. analyze theories of rights and the rule of law and apply these to moral and legal problems;
3. choose position on the basis of theoretical arguments with regard to moral and legal problems such as torture;
4. analyze legal interpretation, particularly in judicial opinions;
5. reflect critically upon theories of legal method;
6. write clear and well-argued statements on the issues under 1 to 5.

column1: The aim of the Life Support course is to give you a basic training in acute medicine and to experience ‘real’ working situations with help of some specially trained actors. The emphasis of the course is on the quick recognition of acute situations, clear communication, and adequate handling. We talk about how situations differ between inside and outside of the hospital, and between first-aid and professional medical care personnel.

During the course, the term ‘victim’ is frequently used. This term indicates a person who has an acute, (non-)life threatening disorder in her/his physical or mental health.  And who, in her/his own opinion or that of others, needs help. The common theme throughout the course is the ABCDE approach. This protocol is used internationally for the structured assessment and care of an acutely ill or wounded patient. In this course, the basic principles of this protocol will be taught. You will also learn e.g. how to assess the safety of a situation, call for help and perform CPR with or without the help an automated external defibrillator (AED).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Following this programme, the student is able to:

column2: • Assess the vital functions according to the ABCDE protocol and provide adequate treatment to disorders of the vital functions;
• Carry out adequate resuscitation according to NRR guidelines when faced with circulatory arrest;
• Provide adequate First Aid to accident victims (including treatment of wounds and bites; bandaging; removing splinters).

column1: This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Hermeneutics understands man as a self-interpreting animal, constructing itself through interpretation of its relation to the other and to historically produced culture. In this course, we will look at recent developments in culture that affect such interpretive self-understanding, and conversely at ways in which contemporary man produces this culture – as man and culture are mutually constitutive phenomena.
This course has two dimensions, which will interactively be presented in alternating weeks.

The first dimension deals with a variety of very recent developments in media, culture and science, such as digitalization, interculturalization and naturalization. The omnipresent informatization challenges hermeneutics to rethink the nature of human interpretation in the age of digital culture. Connecting to the work of Benjamin, Heidegger, and Simondon we will discuss the impact of hypermedia and game culture on writing and reading in the humanities? Secondly, global interculturalization challenges hermeneutics to reflect on the possibility and limits of intercultural understanding and interpretation. Starting from the work of Gadamer and Derrida, the focus will be on the question whether we can understand cultures in which we do not participate or only do so superficially. Thirdly, hermeneutics is challenged by the naturalization brought forth by disciplines like genetics and neurosciences and the accompanying converging technologies. Hermeneutics should not only analyze the impact of the ‘colonization’ of the humanities by the natural sciences in disciplines like evolutionary and  neuropsychological aesthetics, but also study the interpretative metaphors in these disciplines (e.g. ‘reading and writing genetic code’) and – following the work of Plessner, Thompson and Barbieri, - develop bio-hermeneutical, neuro-phenomenological and bio-semiotic complements to these disciplines.

The second dimension provides an analysis from a social and political perspective and discusses the power relations in society that affect, or interferes with, each of the aforementioned developments. This results in three challenges that form a counterpoint to those in the first half of the course. We discuss the phenomenon of mediatization, especially as analyzed by Benjamin in his Artwork essay; the role of the public sphere in relation to power, resistance, communication, and technology; the relation between technology, politics, and the phenomenon of outsourcing, or ‘interpassivity’; and the current issues around algorithms and their influence on politics and biopower.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1) grasping, and be able to productively and creatively work with, the historical and systematic relations between public realm, media, power, interculturalization, and biopolitics.
2) grasping hermeneutically and critically  the transformation of human life through power and global technologies

3) understanding the historical and cultural importance of hermeneutics for philosophy, and the challenges posed to it by the processes of interculturalization, informatization, and naturalization.</body>

column1: Literary movements and - styles do not emerge in a vacuum but are closely related to their proponent’s relation to the literary tradition, their reaction to their social context and their attitudes towards the future. There is, in other words a politics of literature as much as a literature of politics. From the Romantic poet Percy Bysshe Shelly to contemporary hip-hop icon Kendrick Lamar, literary artists have been unambiguously preoccupied with questions of power, resistance and agency. Taking the emergence of ‘modern’ literature around 1800 as a starting point, this course will trace some of the relations between literature and politics up until the present. Rather than privileging one type of politics of literature over the other, students will engage with multifarious constellations of literature and politics through different theoretical orientations, historical contexts and literary genres. Each week will be centred around a particular theme (e.g. Literary Autonomy, The Politics of Literary Form, Literature and Community). We will read theoretical texts in conjunction with literary texts, from graphic novels to radical poetry and from feminist auto-fiction to utopian afrosci-fi. Ultimately, this course aims to provide students with the conceptual and analytical tools to reflect on and reimagine the possible relations between literature and politics.

<body>Tijdens dit blok ga je aan de slag met het schrijven van een wetenschappelijk literatuuronderzoek. Het leren schrijven van een literatuuronderzoek is zeer nuttig, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van leeronderzoeken en scripties, daar het vertrekpunt van al het sociologische onderzoek gevormd wordt door de grondige bestudering van eerder onderzoek. Tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst wordt uitgelegd waar een goed geschreven literatuuronderzoek aan moet voldoen. De daarop volgende bijeenkomsten staan in het teken van het opzetten, schrijven en verbeteren van het literatuuronderzoek; te beginnen met het opstellen van een goede probleemstelling en eindigend met het doen van aanbevelingen voor vervolgonderzoek.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the first week, the course will present the key principles underlying effective local government finance frameworks within the context of intergovernmental fiscal relations and fiscal decentralization. It will review the main revenue sources available to local governments, the issues typically associated with such sources, and the key challenges associated with revenue management. The sources of revenue for local governments discussed include taxes, user fees, and intergovernmental transfers, as well as investment income, property sales, and licenses and permits. The course will also analyse the issues associated with the development of capital investments plans and the corresponding sources of funding. It will cover established and innovative instruments and mechanisms utilized by municipalities to leverage additional resources for financing capital investments through borrowing and accessing capital markets. It will look closely at debt management, creditworthiness, intergenerational equity and the impact of funding from development partners.

During the second week, the course will review some of the key decision analysis theories and approaches related to investment projects, with a focus on economic and financial analysis. The conceptual foundations of economic and financial Cost Benefit Analysis will be addressed by reviewing the key microeconomic concepts that can be applied to the measurement of costs and benefits. The discounted cash flow analysis principle will be applied to concrete examples of investment projects. Among other cash flow modelling, projects lifetime period, net present value, discount rate, and risk will be reviewed. Excel spreadsheets will be used to build an investment decision-making framework related to a hypothetical toll road projects and risk and sensitivity analysis will be carried out to incorporate uncertainty and probability in decision analysis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the course the participant should be able to:

column2: • Understand, explain and discuss the key principles and elements of local government finance including fiscal decentralization, revenue management, and capital investment planning
• Understand and apply economic and financial analysis to investment projects relevant to local governments and incorporate uncertainty and probability in decision analysis

column1: In het zeventiende-eeuwse Engeland vinden grote natuurwetenschappelijke en filosofische veranderingen plaats die zich institutioneel kristalliseren rondom de Royal Society, waarvan eminente wetenschappers als Robert Boyle and Isaac Newton lid waren. Het empirisme van John Locke dient in deze context begrepen te worden. De latere zeventiende eeuw ziet ook een nieuwe generatie van rationalisten als Leibniz en Nicolas Malebranche, die voortgaan met de verdieping van begrippen als 'substantie' en 'causaliteit'. Voorts worden, opnieuw in Engeland, belangrijke bijdragen geleverd aan de politieke filosofie en ethiek door onder anderen Locke, diens leerling de derde graaf van Shaftesbury, en Herman Mandeville.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Op het eind van de cursus hebben de studenten kennis en begrip van de twee belangrijkste kentheoretische stromingen van de zeventiende eeuw en kunnen zij deze plaatsen binnen de contekst van de stormachtige veranderingen op het gebied van de natuurwetenschappen.</body>

column1: Students that would like to gain some practical experience during the Master program, can do so by means of an internship. Students can use one of the elective blocks to do a full time internship.

Instead of an elective a so-called business project can be carried out. This business project will be shorter than a regular internship. The advantage is that such a project can be carried out during one of the three elective blocks. A student can come up with a business project at a company of his or her choice. At the end of the internship the student will hand in a report.

The business project can be related to the thesis. However, this is not a requirement. Please not that even the two are linked, the business project will be assessed separately from the thesis itself and should contain another focus than the thesis. Please consult your thesis coach in case you want to combine your internship with you thesis.
<u>THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR MI STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS</u>: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two MI programme electives!</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In het vak maatschappelijke problemen en bestuurlijke oplossingen maken de studenten kennis met de wereld van de maatschappelijke problemen, het openbaar bestuur en de bestuurskunde. Ze leren in essentie wat het openbaar bestuur is, op welke wijze het openbaar bestuur tracht maatschappelijke problemen op te lossen en wat de rol van het vakgebied van de bestuurskunde hierbij is. Daarbij wordt specifiek ingegaan op de organisatie van het openbaar bestuur en de processen die daarin een rol spelen. De centrale vraag daarbij is welke principes van bestuurlijke vormgeving ten grondslag liggen aan de organisatie van het openbaar bestuur en welke spanningen daarbij kunnen optreden. Deze kennis vormt het basale vertrekpunt voor de verdere opleiding.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92448,2020,Maatschappij en Beleid,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Molenveld', 'dr. W Belabas', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In deze module wordt 'beleid' benaderd vanuit het perspectief van de maatschappij. Niet het perspectief van de overheid wordt dus als vertrekpunt gekozen voor de beschouwing van beleid, maar juist de rol die verschillende coördinatiemechanismen kunnen vervullen in de productie van bepaalde publieke voorzieningen. Daarbij wordt getracht het concept ‘publicness’ op verschillende manieren in te vullen: vanuit de staat, de markt en de gemeenschap. Dit past ook bij de idee dat dat het probleemoplossende vermogen van een samenleving niet alleen wordt bepaald door de aanwezigheid van een overheid of staat die sturingskracht ontwikkelt. Het probleemoplossend vermogen van een samenleving heeft ook te maken met de mate waarin een samenleving over voldoende veerkracht en zelforganiserend vermogen beschikt (of via de markt of via allerlei gemeenschappen), en waarbij de staat of de overheid een andere rol inneemt; een rol die veel eerder coproducerend is dan producerend is. Dit heeft ook gevolgen voor de wijze waarop beleid wordt ontwikkeld en uitgevoerd en hoe beleid, dan kan worden geconceptualiseerd.</body>

column1: Much of the recent success of data-driven approaches in business have been powered by machine learning, a key subfield of artificial intelligence. In this course, we will cover several fundamental machine learning algorithms used by data scientists. Students will learn to apply them in R for solving relevant business problems.

The course will cover several supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms, such as decision trees, random forests, neural networks, cluster analysis and gradient boosting machines. We will also look at the principles and methods required to apply these correctly, such as resampling methods and evaluation metrics.

The content will be divided into modules in a blended learning approach. Students will prepare for class by reading the materials and watching knowledge clips covering each topic. These topics will be further elaborated in the classroom, after which there will be time to practice the application of the methods in R using the supplied notebooks.

•    Apply these machine learning algorithms to business problems and their accompanying data sets in a principled way using R
•    Deliver the results of such applications in presentations and/or reports
•    Apply machine learning methods to solve business problems</body>

column1: Macroeconomics is the study of the structure and working of an economy as a whole, rather than of individual markets. It defines the main variables in the aggregate economy (GDP, inflation, unemployment), and studies how they behave, in particular how they react to economic shocks and policy decisions, over different time horizons. Two important subjects of macroeconomics can be identified: the study of the causes and consequences of short-run fluctuations in national income (the business cycle), and that of the determinants of long-run economic growth (increases in national income). We will see how macroeconomic models and their predictions are used by governments to assist in the development and evaluation of economic policy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will develop a simple macroeconomic model that allows us to analyse the evolution of the main macroeconomic aggregates in the short, medium and long run. We will also critically discuss policy debates, so that we directly observe how economic theory can be used to understand the real world.

The course builds on Macroeconomics I and applies dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models to the analysis of monetary and fiscal policy. It consists of four main parts. In the first part, we compare the inequality implications of a complete markets and a standard incomplete markets model when households face idiosyncratic income risk. Afterwards, we develop a basic competitive equilibrium framework which serves as the main building block for the course. The second part focuses on the role of fiscal policy. Here, effects of government spending, the role of public debt, and optimal taxation under commitment will be discussed. The third part introduces money into the framework and derives principles for optimal monetary policy under perfectly flexible prices. Further, the issues of monetary policy implementation and the determination of the price level will be addressed. The last part extends monetary policy analysis to the case where prices are imperfectly flexible. Within this framework optimal monetary policy under commitment and discretion will be examined.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
Learning goals for this course: students should have learned to
1. understand the link between insurance and individual consumption
2. solve dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models
3. show whether a long-run equilibrium exists and is unique, and derive conditions for a unique and stable set of policy functions
4. formally compute optimal tax and monetary policies in general equilibrium models
5. understand the economic mechanism why a certain policy is optimal</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Management accounting is at the heart of high-quality decision-making. Modern financial managers are not only concerned with how cost data are transformed into accounting information, but more importantly how to use cost accounting information to support decision-making and accomplish organizational goals.

Management accounting is therefore much more than number crunching – ultimately its function is to gather and analyse information to advise strategy and drive sustainable business success. This course provides students with a good exposure to managerial accounting tools and techniques and their practical application to business managers. Students in this course will learn how to combine financial and non-financial data to paint a complete picture of the business and to support several aspects of management. Emphasis will also be given to the emerging role of business analytics to inform business decisions. In addition to accounting and analytical skills, management accounting requires an understanding of the organisation, its business model, its strategic context and its competitive position, as well as being alert to the organisation’s social and environmental responsibilities.

The course should develop the student's understanding, skills, and analytic ability in management accounting to the level where she/he can function effectively as a professional management accountant/financial controller in industry, auditing firms, management consulting, or governmental organizations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students successfully completing this course will be able to:

column2: • Classify and understand different types of costs (e.g., product costs vs. period costs, direct vs. indirect costs, and fixed vs. variable cost) and identify various concepts of costs (e.g., opportunity costs, sunk costs, marginal costs, average costs)
• Understand the flow of data in an accounting information system, apply data analytics techniques, and interpret results to answer business questions
• Develop cost functions, execute a cost-volume-profit analysis and apply alternative cost accounting systems
• Describe a typical organization's process of budget administration and compose the different elements of the master budget
• Distinguish between static and flexible budgets, execute variance analysis to assess organizational performance and formulate improvement plans
• Analyse and evaluate the organizational implications of alternative models of responsibility accounting and performance measurement systems
• Select what accounting information is useful to support internal decision making, planning and control

A Molenveld', 'dr. PM Karre', 'dr. WH Voorberg, MSc', 'prof.dr. MW van Buuren', 'V Visser, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Public Administration experts, both in science and practice, have to contribute to complex societal issues. The knowledge students got in the first two years of their bachelor program enables them to analyse these issues. This module offers them new theoretical, conceptual and practical knowledge and competences to formulate advices and design solutions, to bridge the gap between the current situation (“ist”) and the desired situation (“soll”). Core of the module ‘Organisation and Policy Consultancy” is to enhance these analytical, design-oriented and advising skills of students.

This module builds upon the theoretical approaches presented in the various modules on “Policy” and “Organisation and Management”. Students have to apply their knowledge in policy processes and public organisations, to analyse complex policy and organisational issues and to formulate solution-oriented advices. They develop a repertoire of skills for professional advising. In addition they learn how to assess whether the conditions for successful policy or organizational change are present.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successfully completing this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Describe the relevant aspects of management consultancy and policy advice in the public domain and its contextual factors;
• Describe current trends in management consultancy and policy advice in the public domain;
• Formulate the various steps in consultancy and advice processes and select suitable tools;
• Make a problem analysis / diagnosis of a complex policy or organisational issue;
• Design a policy advice or an organizational change intervention in a concrete case;
• Formulate a convincing, valid and practical usable policy advice or management recommendation;
• Reflect upon the relationship between clients and advisors and the mechanisms and values that constitute this relationship;
• Reflect upon the quality of advising in the public domain and its dark sides;
• Reflect upon the ethical dimensions of consultancy and policy advice;
• Formulate and assess the conditions for successful adoption and uptake of advices in the public domain.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94830,2020,Management Control,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. E Reusen', 'prof.dr. M van Rinsum']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: ​Management Control Systems (MCS) form the bridge between the organization’s strategy and its operations/services. Their purpose is to align managerial behaviour and decision making with organizational strategic goals. Although financial management tools are typically crucial  in an organization’s MCS, the design and use of a MCS does not only require an understanding of accounting techniques. It should also be based on a thorough understanding of how managerial behaviour is influenced by relevant control system elements, such as target setting, performance measurement and monetary incentives. Indeed, as the proper design of MCS is paramount for organizational performance, organizational failure can often be attributed to a poor design or implementation of the organization’s management control system. Past scandals such as the collapse of Enron and the recent crisis in the financial sector can be directly traced back to failures in MCS design. The emphasis of the course is on the analysis and understanding of the drivers of managerial (rational and irrational) decision making in complex organizations rather than on the application of accounting tools often associated with financial management.

The course strongly focuses on the managerial issues faced by CFOs of multinational companies. Meetings are case-based: students discuss (financial) management control topics in close relation to case studies of multinational companies. The assignments/tests will allow students to show their theoretical knowledge, but also their understanding of how to apply it to real-life case situations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students should be familiar with:
• Requirements for effective management control systems to induce goal-congruent behaviour
• Elements of a well-designed Management Control System (MCS)
• Fit between the firm’s MCS and its environment
• Psychological and economic views on decision-making in contemporary organisations

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94976,2020,Management Control,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. E Reusen', 'prof.dr. M van Rinsum']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Management Control is about influencing the behavior of managers to act in line with the organization’s strategic objectives. In this course, we discuss what alternatives organizations have for ensuring good control, and how organizations should choose among control system alternatives. The main emphasis throughout the course will be on financial results control systems, which provide the dominant form of control in the vast majority of organizations. Topics covered include responsibility structures, target setting (as part of organizations’ planning and budgeting processes), performance measurement and evaluation, and the assignment of various forms of organizational rewards (including performance-dependent compensation).

Illustrations based on real-world cases are discussed, demonstrating when particular control systems are effective, and when they lead to dysfunctional managerial behavior. Ample attention is also paid to the fit with the organizational context, such as the strategy, structure, and culture. The latter part of the course extends the key notions of management control from the intra-organizational level to the inter-organizational level, highlighting some of the issues involved in the control of new collaborative settings and configurations, such as joint-ventures and various types of alliances, often involving global alliance partners.

Overall, this course is intended to broaden and deepen your conceptual and technical understanding of accounting as it is used for management control purposes. It will help you learn to make business decisions, evaluate organizational performance, or evaluate others (and/or be evaluated) through the use of financial and nonfinancial information. These are essential skills for your future career, be it in the position of managers, management consultants, or specialists in staff functions such as controllers, auditors, or human resource specialists. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: On completion of this course, students should be able to:
1.    Understand the purpose of a management accounting & control system, and how it relates to strategy implementation;
2.    Describe and evaluate different types of controls dependent on the type of organization and its structure;
3.    List the crucial characteristics of performance measures and apply the principles of performance measurement;
4.    Identify the (dys-)functional effects of performance measurement and reward systems;
5.    Evaluate and use different performance measurement and evaluation techniques, such as EVA and BSC;
6.    Describe the logic behind contingency theory and exemplify how situational factors might influence the management control system in an organization;
7.    Explain the main drivers behind the development and increased importance of inter-organizational relationships and related control issues;
8.    Approach management control related questions from different theoretical perspectives, using economic and behavioral theory;
9.    Identify, analyze and provide solutions to management control problems covered in this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The content is organized into 6 modules (the fourth one over 2 weeks), covering the following

1.    Introduction to quantitative decision making via Decision Trees ( Introduction to mathematical modelling, strengths and limitations, time structure of decisions, handling uncertainty, quantifying the value of information)
2.    Linear Programming (Formulating and solving Linear Programs. The graphical method. Solving LP’s using Microsoft Excel.)
3.    Sensitivity Analysis (Analyzing sensitivity of LP solutions with respect to data.)
4.    Integer Programming (Modeling discrete decisions. Formulating Integer programs, understanding why IP’s are harder to solve, modelling with binary variables)
5.    Incorporating Uncertainty in Linear Programming (2-stage stochastic programming, deterministic equivalent, non-anticipativity, connection with decision trees)
6.    Monte Carlo Simulation (Understanding the flexibility of simulation, creating and running simulation models in Excel)
​Through the course, we will apply the learned tools to areas such as operations and transportation logistics.

Each week we will have 2 sessions. Prior to class you will read the assigned material. During the first session of each week (2 hours 45 minutes) we will review the material and answer questions as well as solve some examples. The second session (1 hours 45 minutes) will be a workshop. You will work on (pre-posted) problems/cases and I will help you with questions/clarifications. Solutions to these problems will become available post-class.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course you will learn how to use data and management science tools and models to make informed decisions in a variety of business contexts. Models are approximations, reflecting the most relevant, but not all, aspects of reality. You will learn to decouple the assumptions from the analysis and develop a well grounded appreciation for the value-adding potential of quantitative thinking but also the need to critically evaluate model outputs.
-    will be able to recognize the types of business problems that can be solved using optimization and simulation methods
-    Understand how optimization and simulation can add value to business and provide a competitive edge
-    Formulate optimization models and solve them using Excel
-    Formulate simulation models and run them using Excel
-    Analyze sensitivity of solutions of decision models
-    Recommend the best course of action based on solutions of optimization and simulation models</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Management Accounting is een vakgebied dat zich richt op het verzamelen, ordenen, interpreteren, presenteren en gebruiken van cost accounting informatie ten behoeve van de besluitvorming door het management in organisaties.

Management accounting is derhalve veel meer dan louter rekenwerk of “number crunching” – het ultieme doel is de besluitvorming te ondersteunen en duurzame organisatiedoelen te bereiken. Dit vak geeft studenten een goede inleiding tot management accounting tools en technieken en de praktische toepassing hiervan voor moderne financiële managers. Studenten leren in dit vak hoe financiële en niet-financiële informatie te combineren, en op een vertrouwde manier met data-analyse om te gaan. Naast accounting en analytische vaardigheden, vereist management accounting een goed begrip van de organisatie, het businessmodel, de strategische context en positie in de markt, met aandacht voor duurzaam beleid.

De cursus zal het inzicht, de vaardigheden en het analytisch vermogen in management accounting van de student ontwikkelen tot het niveau waar hij/zij effectief kan functioneren als een professionele management accountant/financial controller in het bedrijfsleven, accountantskantoren, management consulting, of overheidsinstellingen</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• De verschillende typen kosten in organisaties te classificeren (bv. productkosten vs. periodekosten, directe vs. indirecte kosten, vaste vs. variabele kosten) en diverse kostenconcepten te identificeren (bv. opportuniteitskosten, gezonken kosten, marginale kosten, gemiddelde kosten)
• Technieken in data-analyse te begrijpen, toe te passen, en resultaten te interpreteren, ter ondersteuning van de besluitvorming
• Kostenfuncties te ontwikkelen, cost-volume-profit analyses uit te voeren, en alternatieve kostenallocatietechnieken toe te passen
• Het budget proces in een organisatie te beschrijven en de budgetschema’s die samen het master budget vormen op te stellen
• Statische en flexibele budgetten te onderscheiden en variantieanalyses uit te voeren om prestaties te evalueren en verbeterplannen voor te stellen
• Implicaties voor organisaties van alternatieve modellen van responsibility accounting en prestatiemeting te bepalen
• Accounting informatie te selecteren die relevant is om interne plannings-, beleids- en beheersingsbesluiten te nemen

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The current challenges in media organizations and the media industry, such as the ongoing COVID-19 crisis, more generally a growing mediatization of organizations and society, rising competition, and an increasing complexity of organizational issues make managing and leading processes and practices of strategy and change highly relevant.

Therefore, the course provides an overview of key theories and topics around strategy, management and leadership and works towards their reflective adaptation and implementation in media organizations and other mediated contexts. Students will comprehend and evaluate classical and modern approaches from managing change and strategy to competitive forces, industry analysis, resources and strategy processes and practices.

On this basis, we will discuss the possibilities of managing and leading individuals, teams and organizations through communication in strategic manner. Through diverse activities, students will apply these theories and approaches sensibly and creatively for learning how to develop successful actions in/for practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Current concepts, approaches and theories of strategic management and leadership that are relevant for working in media organizations;
• How media organizations and practitioners strategically manage processes and practices around individuals, groups,  and organization-wide phenomena.
• Identify the need for and function of strategic management and leadership in their context;
• Apply strategy and leadership approaches and theories reflectively;
• Lead social and organizational action through communication.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will provide insights into the complex topic of diversity in organizations and will examine how diversity can effectively be managed in organizations. At the end of the course, students understand the core diversity theories and empirical research insights, can critically evaluate the operation and effects of diversity across individual, team, and organizational levels, and apply their learnings to real-world diversity challenges by identifying how human resource management (HRM) can contribute to the effective management of diversity in organizations.  </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column4: Learning ares
Learning outcomes
I. Content-related
Having an understanding of the core diversity theories and most relevant scholarly insights on diversity.
Being able to approach diversity from a holistic perspective considering its complexity operating across levels (individual, team, organization) and contexts.
II. Skills-related
Being able to apply diversity theory and research to real-world challenges around the management of diversity.
Knowing how to have meaningful and evidence-based discussions about the management of diversity at work.
III. Attitude-related
Using an evidence-based mindset to approach diversity management in the most effective way.
Being able and willing to critically reflect upon on one’s own perceptions about diversity.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92267,2020,Management of Media and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. HJCJ Hitters'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This seminar focuses on organizational aspects of the media and creative industries and the strategic conduct of firms. The central question is to what extent firms in the media and cultural industries are different from other firms with respect to initiating, managing and controlling business processes. This question will be analyzed from three angles. We will first systematically and critically assess the nature and structure of creative media markets, in which symbolic or experience value plays an important role and companies have to operate in a dynamic field of continuous technological, social and cultural transformations. Secondly, whereas most management literature centers on strategies of large cross-media corporations, in this seminar we aim at understanding the conduct and business ventures of small-scale enterprises and entrepreneurs (SMSE’s). These are mostly positioned at the beginning of the creative value chain: the phase of concept and idea creation and the first stages of production. After all, at this stage successful management of creativity is crucial to innovation. The third angle examines the relationship between incumbents and new enterprises in the media and creative industries. Here we will focus on issues such as innovation failure, routines, leadership and transformation. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The specific character of organization and management in the media and creative industries.
• Current theories, approaches and debates in this field.
• Systematically analyze and critically reflect on fundamental and practical challenges in managing and organizing contemporary media and creative industries firms.
• Find alternatives and solutions for challenges that media and creative companies are facing.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95343,2020,Management van technologie,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. DA Stam'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Technologie is al eeuwenlang één van de belangrijkste pijlers van de economie. Zowel in de productiegerichte sectoren als in dienstverlenende bedrijven speelt technologie een belangrijke rol. Zonder technologische vooruitgang verliezen bedrijven concurrentiekracht. Managers staan voor de vraag op welke manier zij optimaal gebruik kunnen maken van technologie. Welke technologie is beschikbaar en welke technologische ontwikkelingen zijn gaande? Welke gevolgen kan technologie hebben voor een bedrijf, een sector en de maatschappij? Welke betekenis heeft technologie voor de strategie van het bedrijf wat betreft de producten/diensten, de productieprocessen, en de kerncompetenties? Kortom, hoe kunnen managers technologieën herkennen en op een juiste wijze inpassen binnen het bedrijf? In dit vak zul je een technologie strategie ontwikkelen voor een high-tech technologie toegepast in een kernproduct van het casebedrijf door technische en bedrijfskundige criteria te combineren.

Het vak staat in het teken van management van “high-tech” technologieën. Je zult kijken naar een specifieke “high-tech” technologie die een essentieel onderdeel is van een product (B2B of B2C) van het bedrijf dat jouw case heeft ingebracht. Deze technologie kan echter verouderen vanwege opkomende nieuwe technologieën. De opkomende technologieën hebben dezelfde functionaliteit als de huidige technologie, maar zouden (in de toekomst) meer waarde kunnen toevoegen aan het product van het bedrijf en zijn klanten. Daarom is het belangrijk om de technologische ontwikkelingen te volgen en te overwegen om voor een opkomende technologie te kiezen om de concurrenten voor te blijven. Hierbij gaat het niet om de vraag hoe aan een marktvraag kan worden voldaan door middel van technologie (“market pull”), maar hoe technologieën kunnen worden benut voor de vernieuwing van de producten/diensten, de productieprocessen, en de kerncompetenties van een bedrijf (“technology push”).

Het is echter niet vanzelfsprekend om over te stappen op een (technologisch gezien) beter alternatief. Het introduceren van een opkomende technologie kan grote effecten hebben op het product, het productieproces, het bedrijf zelf en zijn omgeving. Daarom moeten managers de opkomende en de huidige technologieën zorgvuldig evalueren en met elkaar vergelijken, inclusief hun effecten. De hoofdvraag in dit vak luidt dan ook: moet het bedrijf overstappen op een van de opkomende technologieën?

Het doel van het vak is het schrijven van een strategisch plan voor een bestaand bedrijf (case bedrijf) met een high-tech product waarin een alternatieve technologie kan worden toegepast. Om dit doel te behalen moet je eerst de huidige situatie verkennen (opdracht 1). Daarna zul je geschikte opkomende technologieën analyseren en hun eventuele impact op het bedrijf onderzoeken (opdracht 2). Vervolgens combineer je deze informatie in een voorstel voor een technologie strategie (opdracht 3), welke je zult samenvatten tijdens een presentatie voor je medestudenten.

Het vak kan gerelateerd worden aan SDG Goal 9: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation. Onderdeel van opdracht 2 en 3 is het in acht nemen van de (maatschappelijke) omgeving bij de implementatie van de opkomende technologieën.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Strategic management is concerned with what is perhaps the most pressing issue for practicing managers: how can I make my firm outperform its competitors? To formulate such value-creating strategies, managers must identify a suitable business model, formulate growth strategies, identify core capabilities, and develop new ways of outcompeting their rivals. Firms are also increasingly confronted with more multifaceted environments such as business ecosystems as well respond to rapid technological innovations, such as for example new digital technologies. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge and skills needed to accomplish these activities and navigate the strategic decision-making process in an increasingly uncertain and complex business environment.

The emphasis in this class lies not on identifying the “right” answer, instead the focus is on creating a learning environment that stimulates students’ critical engagement with the study material. Teaching methods therefore include a combination of lectures, plenary discussions, guest lectures, webcasts, group exercises and case work. Students are expected to prepare the assigned material and webcasts prior to each class in order to be able to be able to contribute to the interactive classroom discussions as well as being able to complete in-class group exercises.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: •    To describe the value of scientific research for business strategy practice;
•    To integrate different theoretical perspectives to develop business strategies under uncertainty and ambiguity to realize organizational goals;
•    To evaluate what capabilities influence firms’ ability to successfully outperform its competitors in dynamic industries;
•    To analyze present strategic problems and opportunities at the business level;
•    To create, evaluate and make decisions about strategic options for addressing these present issues; and
•    To give oral presentations about a strategic problem within a company.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>By studying relevant literature on cultural heritage management, students will gain knowledge of the intertwining character of heritage, tourism, economy, culture and (local) identity. Subsequently they will be challenged to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete case studies which will require them to carry out field work on location. The course will highlight the strategies that can be put in place to ensure the better preservation possible of cultural heritage while stimulating tourism. Literature discussions, interviews and field trips will provide a varied didactic program with a hands-on attitude.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete real-life cases. Students become familiar with the major trends and challenges in the world of cultural heritage management and how heritage management could go together with place-making and the creation of sustainable tourism. Moreover, students will gain knowledge of the experiences of various actors in the field of cultural heritage management and their insider’s view on current developments.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/91511,2020,Managing Individuals & Teams,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J Alkema', 'dr. JN Mell']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: There is a growing realization that organizational success and the ability of organizations to gain a competitive advantage is critically contingent on effective management of people. This course aims to develop an in-depth understanding of the social, psychological, and organizational factors that shape individuals’ behaviour at work and allow for effective collaboration, covering topics such as motivation, decision making, team composition and effective collaboration, and power dynamics. Building on BA teaching in OB and HRM, in this course we will deepen this knowledge and place a particular emphasis on the link between theory and managerial practice. The resulting principles of people management are a valuable part of any future manager’s toolbox, but they are particularly critical for future HR professionals.

The course proceeds in a highly interactive way, each class combining multiple different learning activities. Selected book chapters and academic articles provide essential background knowledge for class activities and must be completed prior to the start of each class. Lecture elements supplement information gained from the reading assignments and integrate course material. Experiential exercises and simulations deepen the insight on specific social and psychological phenomena. Case discussions train the application of course knowledge to solve managerial problems. During the course, students are expected to actively participate in class discussions and activities.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1.    Understand core theories in the area of organizational behavior, including job satisfaction and well-being, individual differences, motivation, teams, and leadership.
2.    Apply organizational behavior theories in order to analyze challenges facing current-day organizations.
3.    Develop theoretically sound and practical recommendations to challenges related to managing individuals and teams in organizations.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94522,2020,Managing Innovation Strategically,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. H Fasaei'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Increasingly, in today’s fast paced, converging world, sustained innovation is a necessity not only to thrive but also to survive. However, for most firms, the strategies and processes associated with innovation remain vague and are not strategically managed. As a result, most firms are unable to innovate successfully and thus create meaningful value for their consumers.

In this course, we will learn why firms struggle to create and capture meaningful value for their consumers. The aim of the course is to provide a set of concepts as well as practical tools and processes that can be used by managers in their organizations to manage innovation more strategically. The main topics that we'll discuss in this course include: disruptive innovation, the innovator's dilemma, innovation challenges, consumer resistance to innovation, a service lens to innovation and job-to-be-done perspective, value proposition innovation, empathy mapping, business model innovation, experience design and management, and communicating innovation persuasively.

The format is in such a way that allows you to focus on the subject matter and to have engaging debates in the classroom. Therefore, this course will provide you with an insightful and fun learning environment. Applying the theoretical and practical knowledge is a central aspect of this course. Therefore, it will include several practical examples and cases. In some sessions we will use case studies. In order to have interesting sessions and to benefit from them to the fullest, you need to come to the class prepared.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and explain the importance of strategic innovation
• Recognize, understand and explain the determinants of managing innovation strategically and innovation challenges
• Be able to put on a service lens toward innovation and devise innovative value propositions accordingly
• Be able to innovate in relation to business model of the organization
• Be able to communicate innovation persuasively via strategic storytelling

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94657,2020,Managing Interactive Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. IF van Meerkerk', 'dr. MJ Nederhand']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course focuses on management in the context of interactive governance. Interactive forms of governance are on the rise in many countries. They refer to processes in which multiple governmental and non-governmental actors interact in formulating or implementing public policy. services and decision-making. In addition to other courses in the Master programs, this course pays specific attention to both government-induced forms of interactive governance (e.g. citizen participation) and citizen-induced forms of interactive governance (e.g. community-based initiatives and community-led co-production). The first means that governments organize citizen involvement in complex projects; the latter indicates that citizens themselves show self-organizing capacity and initiative for the preparation, implementation and maintenance of public services in different sectors for example: sustainable energy, health and urban development.

These interactive forms of governance offer important potential for enhancing effectiveness, public support, empowerment and democratic quality of policy and decision-making processes, but are also challenging existing ways of working within governments. Moreover, they are not self-executive and a variety of factors and obstacles may prevent this potential to become manifest. They could also raise issues of accountability, inclusion and transparency. This course focuses on the potential and challenges of interactive governance and how specific management strategies and process designs could deal with these challenges and how they could enhance the democratic quality and effectiveness of interactive governance.

In a systematic way, the various conditions and barriers for effective and legitimate interactive governance are discussed. Secondly, relevant strategies, behavior and skills of managers are discussed to deal with these barriers. In this regard specific attention is paid to boundary spanning activities and skills in connecting governmental and non-governmental actors. Thirdly, a hands-on and reflective approach is taken. Students are challenged to critically reflect on cases and literature and to formulate practical advice to managers engaged in interactive governance.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After completion of the course students are able:

column2: • To understand the differences between government-induced (participation) and citizen-induced (self-organization) interactive governance approaches and processes;
• To apply different perspectives on interactive governance;
• To analyze barriers and challenges of government- and citizen-induced interactive governance;
• To formulate critical conditions for effective and legitimate government- and citizen-induced interactive governance;
• To determine management strategies for interactive governance fitting specific case study circumstances and situations;
• To formulate practical advice and guidelines for managers dealing with interactive governance processes and projects.
