https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94478,2020,Managing NGOs,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['AJK Turkenburg, MSc', 'prof.dr. LCPM Meijs', 'PSM van Overbeeke, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the moment, Western governments are still making budget cuts in order to repair the damage caused by the financial crisis and Covid-19, handing over more responsibilities to its citizens. On the other hand, Covid-19 also lead to more centralized governmental control. Meanwhile, businesses are reorganizing, which often means that they are slimming down, with many employees declared redundant. In the Arab world, citizens are still calling upon their government to take its responsibilities. In North-Korea every step of the average citizen is still monitored. And the BRIC countries are experiencing an economic rollercoaster like never before.

Nowadays, in many countries the power of government is still fading. Governments have failed to solve social issues and have diminished in scope. In addition, we do not only look to government anymore to solve the social issues of our time, use ally. New parties are playing an increasingly decisive role in the political and social arenas: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

What is often forgotten as an important actor in society is the civil society sphere in which philanthropic nongovernmental and non-profit organizations are active. These organizations often focus on societal issues, such as the need for distributing medical care for those who have little access to it, to reduce poverty, reduce emissions, save the whales or advocate for human rights. Many of them are focused upon advocating governments and businesses to take their responsibilities. Others are collaborating with these organizations to gain additional resources. Just like business and governments, the context in which these NPOs and NGOs operate is very diverse (maybe even more diverse!). Just like for-profit organizations, many different types of NPOs and NGOs exist. Just like for-profit organizations, these organizations serve a mission and have their particular strategies. As such, just like for-profit organizations, these organizations need to be managed properly in order to achieve their goals. In this course, you will see however, that the way in which these organizations are managed, is completely different than in the for-profit or governmental sector.

During the elective, you will be provided with a theoretical and practical background of the management of philanthropic, non-profit and nongovernmental organizations. During a number of guest lectures, organizations will provide an insight into the management of their NPO or NGO. During these lectures, specific themes within management of philanthropic organizations are highlighted and investigated.

During the assignments you will be actively connecting research and practice based up on pragmatic real-life issues of NPOs. Although the cases are presented as fictive, experiences of previous years show that we are able to share your reports with many NPOs/NGOs in our network. Next to the lectures given by Prof. Dr. Lucas Meijs (Professor of Strategic Philanthropy and Volunteering) a number of guest lectures from the field are part of the elective. Moreover, fieldtrips to NPOs/NGOs will be arranged for you to be able to take a look into what really happens at these organisations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this elective, you will be able to
•    Understand the functioning and complexity of non-profit, nongovernmental and philanthropic organizations and the civil society;
•    Understand the management aspects of non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic organization;
•    Analyse the management aspects non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic organization;
•    Analyse specific challenges these organizations are facing in the contemporary context;
•    Evaluate your insights into practical issues of running a non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic organization;
•    Understand, analyse and evaluate the way in which the civil society sphere creates impact and interacts with and is related to the business and the governmental sphere.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94519,2020,Managing Performance of Manufacturing and Service Systems,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Roy'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The main topics to be covered include the following ones
- Developing quantitative models and estimating performance measures
- Generating system insights and improving performance

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Companies of all kinds -- manufacturing or services – believe that their customers are most important and valuable assets. Strong customer focus is often identified as the most important
differentiator between the best and the worst companies. Hence, managing customer experience and guaranteeing a certain service level is of paramount importance.

Performance management in manufacturing and service companies is often complex because the performance is affected by coordination requirements among multiple resources and the customer. To understand the objective of this course better, consider “time” as the performance measure reflecting customer experience. For instance, in a manufacturing system, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires coordination among several resources such as, supplier (providing the raw material), planner (planning the machine capacity), scheduler (scheduling the job), worker (working on machine setup), and machine (processing the job). Therefore, lower is the coordination delays among the resources, better is the performance measure positively affecting the customer experience. Likewise, in a service system such as a restaurant, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires minimizing coordination delays among the tables (seating the customer), order takers (taking the order), and kitchen resources (preparing the food). Hence, to manage manufacturing and service system performance, there is a growing importance on analyzing the system and estimating the measures that are good indicators of customer experience such as customer “waiting time.”

This course will focus on approaches to estimate the performance measures and design systems for superior performance. The complexities in managing customer performance are further increased because of the sources of uncertainties present in the system such as uncertain number of customer arrivals. The students will also learn approaches to manage system performance in the presence of business uncertainties. Through this course, the students will develop skills in building quantitative models for manufacturing and service systems, which can be analyzed rapidly to provide insights for decision making. We will also try to incorporate behavioural aspects of service and manufacturing operations in the quantitative models. The skills will be developed through a mix of concept lectures, cases, experimenting with software tools, and a course project.  Some prior exposure to simulation tools will be helpful to keep pace with the course learnings.

The students will develop analytical thinking and learn to deal with practical issues while executing the course project, develop skills for quick performance analysis of systems, and also learn to develop managerial insights from models, which is an important skill to possess for executing complex on-the-job assignments in manufacturing and service organizations. The concepts discussed in each lecture will build on the learnings from the previous lectures. Hence, the students are advised to prepare thoroughly with the course material. A detailed course outline will be posted on Canvas.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94762,2020,Managing Professional Organisations,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Sergeeva'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Professional service firms can be considered the most central change agent of our day and age: a new management theory is applied and spread by consultants, the physical environment is developed by engineers, controlling business is delegated to accountants and when all this does not succeed we rely on the help of lawyers. This indicates that professionals are ubiquitous in business life and justifies deeper research in the management of Professional Service Firms (PSFs). In this course we will consider PSFs for the ‘classical’, officially accredited professionals such as lawyers and accountants, and the less ‘official’ professionals such as IT experts, consultants and creative professionals. We will classify them all as knowledge-intensive organizations. The course will focus on two broad questions: (1) how are such knowledge-intensive organizations structured, governed, and managed internally? (2) how do such organizations interact with high velocity environment in which they operate? The last point represents an external view and hints at organizational change and learning. In this course we will first introduce defining features of PSFs. Further, we will discuss definitions of knowledge – with a special emphasis on a social-constructivist view - and how knowledge matters for PSFs. Subsequently, we will examine forms of governance typical for PSFs; discuss how organizational members manage tension between economic and professional goals; unpack how PSFs interact with their clients. We will conclude by adopting change perspective to understand how professionals as thought leaders keep up with the institutionalized standards of professional excellence and push these standards forward.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: • To understand the socially constructed nature of knowledge and hence of knowledge work and its effects for knowledge worker
• To develop a theoretical basis for understanding the structure and processes within a PSF
• To be aware of the specific working conditions and working context of a professional/knowledge worker and critically reflect on the implications for the personal career
• To get a basic understanding of consultancy methods and the assumptions behind as used in consultancy

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92560,2020,Managing Societal and Institutional Transitions,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. IF van Meerkerk', 'prof.dr. DA McCauley']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Public and private organisations are now confronting highly volatile multi-level political, economic and environmental realities. Global destabilization is underway involving key uncertainties characterized by climate breakdown, the dwindling influence of Western dominated international institutions, the rise of non-governmental influence and anti-establishment social movements, all in the midst of a new technological revolution which will see the rise of automation, artificial intelligence and the dismantling of traditional labour-capital frameworks. This course seeks to help you understand how societal organisations prepare for this future. It introduces you to the idea of how best to manage societal and institutional transitions within the context of global destabilization through robustly planning for strategically developed future scenarios. The course involves a twin track process of (1) lectures that give you a grounding on key uncertainties facing organisations and then (2) group work where you understand how to scenario plan based upon approaches used by organsations such as Royal Dutch Shell and a wide range of other private and public institutions. The written examination will then focus on the lecture material on key uncertainties in global societal and institutional transitions, whilst the group project examines your group work on scenario planning on behalf of a private or public organisation of your choice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Learning goals. By the end of this course, students will be able to;

column2: • Identify the ways in which government, business and NGOs plan for future transitions
• Apply future scenario planning on behalf of an organisation
• Explain the changing roles of institutions in guiding society through transitions
• Explain how societal actors seek to exert influence by strategizing possible futures
• Explain key uncertainties such as climate change, the technological revolution and the rise of new powers
• Identify the main challenges and opportunities for governing transitions

column1: Utilize approaches to assess plans, strategies, policy documents and institutional arrangements for transitions</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94511,2020,Managing technology alliances and acquisitions,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. K Kavusan'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As the rate of innovation increases and competition intensifies at the global level, even the largest companies require knowledge, ideas and capabilities from beyond their boundaries to develop innovations. Alliances and acquisitions are therefore becoming increasingly important corporate development activities for many companies to tap into external knowledge sources. Large firms frequently acquire and ally with younger and smaller companies to combine their innovation potential with their own resources and expertise. Smaller firms, including start-ups, need these partnerships with larger firms to convert their innovative ideas into economic value. Realizing the potential benefits of alliances and acquisitions in generating innovations is however no simple task: it requires a careful evaluation of potential alliance partners and acquisition targets, as well as of different knowledge utilization strategies, in terms of their suitability for a company`s innovation-related goals. In this course, we will discuss the benefits of innovation-oriented alliances and acquisitions, challenges of managing them as well as the ways to overcome these challenges. The knowledge and analytical skills gained in this course will be particularly valuable for students seeking a career in high-technology industries, corporate strategy, and consulting.

In each session we will discuss a particular aspect of innovation through alliances and acquisitions in the context of a real-life case based on the insight from course readings. Each session will have 2-3 core points, and the lecturing will focus on the core theory for each point. For a thorough understanding of these points it is essential to read the course readings before each session. You will be randomly assigned to teams of 4 students to work on in-class assignments and the team project. Team compositions will be announced on Canvas before the first session.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successfully completing the course the participants will be able to:
•    describe the role of alliances and acquisitions in developing innovation outcomes;
•    distinguish between different strategies for utilizing external technological knowledge through alliances;
•    identify criteria for selection of alliance partners and acquisition targets to achieve the innovation goals of a company;
•    evaluate acquisition integration choices and their performance consequences form a technological knowledge point of view;
•    compare different strategies for internationalizing R&D activities.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94518,2020,Managing the Family Business,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. G Criaco'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Family firms are ubiquitous across space, time and industries. Family businesses do not only represent small, private companies. Founders or founding families are important controlling owners of large corporations listed on stock exchanges around the world. Famous examples of family businesses are IKEA, Harley Davidson and Heineken. As such, family businesses represent a very important force for the economic and social development anywhere in the world. Family control, however, raises unique challenges as well as value-creating opportunities for family businesses and their different stakeholders, such as customers, financiers, suppliers, partners, employees, board members and owners.

This course introduces students to the widespread, yet complex, phenomenon of family business. It touches upon several important themes, such as strategy development, succession, governance, conflicts, business continuation, and more. The aim of this course is to introduce concepts and practical learning situations which will help the students to make sense of family businesses and to assist them in better understanding and dealing with the unique challenges and opportunities faced by different family business stakeholders.

The course is specially designed for those who are interested in working in family businesses (e.g., as managers and/or owners) or with family businesses (e.g., as advisors or consultants), and for those coming from a family business background. Whatever their future role will be, students will find it useful to understand the uniqueness of these organizations. During the course, the students will develop their own perspective on family business. After the course, the students should be able to apply in practice appropriate models and theories presented during the course, as well as critically examine models and theories regarding family business

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completion of the course, the student will be able to:
•    Understand common characteristics and challenges of family businesses
•    Describe the main theories and concepts within the field of family business research and practice
•    Demonstrate an ability to analyze and apply family business theories and concepts to different critical situations faced by family businesses
•    Critically evaluate the use of concepts and models to understand family businesses
•    Demonstrate an ability to reflect upon common challenges facing family businesses in practice, and develop a way to address these challenges
In addition to these content-specific objectives, the student will also be able to:
•    Demonstrate an ability to work with others in a professional manner while attempting to achieve a common goal
•    Demonstrate an ability to think critically by identifying, analyzing and providing concrete solutions to complex problems, both in a team and individually

column1: Through drawing on both Global History and International Relations Theory this course explores the concept and history of empire from 1600 through to the present. The first part of this course reflects on the nature and characteristics of empires, through asking questions like: How can we define empire through the ages? How do empires shape the global international order? How are empires established and why do they endure and/or fall? How have empires historically legitimised their existence and expansion? And why, after being a dominant form of political organisation throughout history, have empires seemingly declined in the present? The second part of the course explores the rise and fall of several prominent global empires, to include the seaborne Atlantic and colonial empires of Europe, the steppe empires of Russia and, arguably, China, and the revisionist empire that is the United States of America.

As may be expected, this course has a substantial workload, both in terms of reading and assignments, but as such it constitutes an excellent first step towards identifying a topic for the MA thesis as well as researching and writing up the MA thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Drawing on History and IR, students can conceptualise empire and global order;
• Students can analyse and compare the development of empires in world history;
• Students can discern various scholarly views on the rise and decline of empires and how this affects the global order;

• Through a variety of assignments, students can show that they are able to criticise defend and navigate scholarly opinions to develop their own substantiated views on key episodes of the history of empire and global order.

column1: This course focuses on the law and practice of marine insurance. Students learn about how ship-owners, charterers and cargo owners may obtain insurance cover against typical marine risks such as loss of or damage to ship’s hull and machinery, cargo damage and third-party liabilities. The course follows a theme-by-theme approach and draws comparisons between how these aspects are dealt with in case of a Hull & Machinery (H&M), a Protection & Indemnity (P&I) or a Marine Cargo insurance cover. The course adopts a comparative law perspective. Even though the starting point is the English Marine Insurance Act, this will be contrasted with provisions from civil law jurisdictions such as Title 7.17 of the Dutch Civil Code and from the Principles of European Insurance Contract Law (PEICL). Standard policy wordings such as the Institute Clauses and Club Rules are used as reference points where appropriate. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. Students need to prepare assignment that will be discussed during seminars. The course will be graded based on the assignments (20%) and a written essay exam (80%).

column1: <body>To provide students with an overview and understanding of various legal issues and practical problems which are specific to the law and practice of the insurance of marine risks.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94015,2020,Maritime Casualties,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'dr. P Wilinski', 'mr. WP Sprenger', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course examines the complex legal relations and liabilities which arise when a ship at sea is in distress and/or suffers a maritime casualty. The course gives an overview of the many international legal instruments which (may) apply to various as-pects of a maritime casualty. It addresses the various mechanisms designed to pre-vent maritime casualties and marine pollution from occurring by raising the technical and safety standards of and on board of ships. These mechanisms include Flag- and Port-State Control, the Paris MoU and the role of Classification Societies.

Other subjects covered in depth include the law of Collision, Salvage, General Ave-rage, Limitation of Liability of the ship-owner, Civil Liability for Oil Pollution damage and Wreck Removal. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. The course will be examined on the basis of a written exam consisting of essay questions. Several lectures and/or workshops will be taught by guest lecturers from maritime practice.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>To provide students with a thorough understanding of both law and practice with regard to the area of maritime casualties.</body>

column1: In this course, the characteristics and management of markets are described in topics that include the marketing environment, components of the marketing mix, market segmentation, and planning. How do companies decide what products to sell or what services to provide? Is it important when the companies introduce the products/services into the marketplace? How do they know who will buy the product or use the service? What are some innovative new products/services that you think will experience growth in the next five years? What makes you think that these items will be successful? In completing this course you will explore some of the basic elements of marketing and answer these and other questions as you research and construct marketing functions as they apply to products/services currently on the market. The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three C’s (customers, company and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s) and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four P’s (product offering, pricing, promotion and physical distribution).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course you will be able to:

column2: • Understand the fundamental principles of marketing, the key elements in developing and planning a marketing strategy, and the determinants of consumer behaviour;
• Master a set of analytical tools (i.e., frameworks, concepts, models, and techniques) for the evaluation and development of marketing efforts;
• Understand the practical relevance and use of the theory through exposure to examples of how companies organize their marketing efforts across a variety of business settings;
• Critically evaluate on organizational/ marketing problems by applying learned theories;
• Critically reflect on a number of ethical considerations raised by marketing practices and navigate ethical dilemmas in the marketplace.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: “Marketing Analytics” refers to a broad range of activities that use data to improve marketing decisions. As the amount of data available continues to increase, companies of all types continue to embrace this exciting and growing field. Companies are increasingly seeking to hire individuals who possess both analytical skills and business knowledge.

Marketers who work with data need to possess a diverse skill set. Although experience with programming and statistics is important, technical skills alone are typically not sufficient for success. Rather, one must understand the broader business context in order to sensibly interpret technical results. Moreover, the ability to clearly and persuasively communicate insights to managers is essential for success.

This elective course provides hands-on opportunities for you to develop and integrate these diverse skills. In the first half of the course, we emphasize the technical—reinforcing the skills you obtained from your previous course work (e.g., statistical analysis of data, multiple regression), while introducing new ones (e.g., advanced data visualization, demand estimation). In the second half of the course, we emphasize the practical—applying these skills to solve managerial problems and communicate your recommendations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: -    Understand and explain the intuition behind technical concepts used by marketing analysts
-    Manipulate and summarize data using the R programming language
-    Draw inferences from data to answer questions relevant to marketing managers
-    Use R to graphically represent data and inferences; recognize and evaluate alternative presentation strategies
-    Explain and justify managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through written reports

It is not possible to train you to become a marketing analyst in six weeks, however it is possible to train you to become an analytics-savvy marketer, and that is the main goal of this course. Having said that, some (former) students have used this course as a starting point for careers as marketing analysts.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92039,2020,Marketing Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AC Crotta', 'dr. ASV Radermecker', 'L Marques', 'MF Rodriguez Rodriguez']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Marketing has become increasingly important as cultural and creative organizations need to generate more income from private sources such as ticket sales or sponsoring. They need to appeal to potential consumers by, e.g., having a clear and appealing identity, communicating and bonding effectively with their audiences, or offering arrangements attracting new audiences. Thus, arts organizations need to prove their relevance time and again in a world where the preferences, expectations and needs of their current and potential audiences are shifting constantly. Marketing is an indispensable tool to shape the relation with the public into a meaningful mutual commitment.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will introduce students to the principles of art marketing. On the one hand, students will learn which characteristics of potential audience members determine their interest in the arts and how this interest may be increased. On the other hand, students are introduced to marketing strategies employed by cultural organizations and the rationale behind them.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94855,2020,Marketing Beyond Borders: Managing Cross Cultural Challenges,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. AK Klesse'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the twenty-first century, the market growth of well-developed and affluent countries has slowed and more and more companies turn(ed) toward emerging markets where the potential is much bigger. Within emerging markets, companies shift their attention from the affluent society to the growing middle class. These changes confront companies with the challenge of operating and competing in very different markets and targeting various consumer segments with heterogeneous needs and preferences. Notably, several large multinational firms have seen their profits decline because they ignored the influence of culture, centralized their marketing, and lacked an understanding of local differences (De Mooij and Hofstede 2002).

This course provides you with a solid understanding of cross-cultural differences and their impact on marketing strategy in an attempt to prepare you for a professional career as a Global Product/Brand Manager (or related functions). We will get to know several cultural frameworks, utilize them to predict consumer behavior, and derive important managerial implications for various Marketing activities (such as Marketing research or branding). To assure high practical relevance, this course incorporates a team assignment with a multi-national company: you will work (in teams) on a real-life problem/challenge and present your findings to the company during a presentation day.

Notably, this course differs from other Marketing courses (e.g., Marketing strategy or Consumer Behavior) in its strong focus on cross-cultural differences; we will emphasize the challenges and problems that arise when applying established marketing concepts (with or without adaptation) in various different (developed and emerging) markets.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Understand how cultural profiles can be used to predict differences in consumer behavior across markets
• Be able to define Global Marketing Strategy and distinguish between different perspectives (e.g., standardization/adaptation, configuration and integration of value chain)
• Recognize cross-cultural challenges that arise when companies operate beyond borders for various Marketing domains (e.g., Marketing research or Branding)
• Get to know different strategies that companies apply to globalize; understand their advantages and challenges
• Understand how (and which) cross-cultural differences could impact consumer behavior and then develop corresponding managerial implications
• Develop a marketing strategy for existing products/brands for a specific market (real life business case)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94558,2020,Marketing Honours Class,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AK Klesse', 'dr. CJP Lembregts']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A limited group of 20-25 students will be selected to follow an additional course that runs across the 3rd and 4th block of their studies. During the sessions, faculty members and marketing practitioners will discuss relevant and current themes in marketing, such as branding and social media.

Researchers within the department will present their own and others’ latest research in these areas and discuss it with the students. Practitioners and alumni will be invited to some of the sessions to give the programme a more applied flavour. The programme will also feature company visits. The sessions will be highly interactive and require a strong preparation consisting of reading and summarizing relevant literature. Cooperation will be sought with external partners, who will discuss the topics from their practical perspective.

Participation will be limited to the best students in the MSc programme of Marketing Management. The first step in the selection process will be a ranking based on all core courses (Blocks 1 and 2, weighted by ECTS). In the second step in the selection process, the highest ranking students will be asked to submit a motivation letter.</body>

The course is designed to complement the MSc course portfolio by offering more in-depth training in selected areas of particular interest. The programme is also designed to facilitate the transition from marketing student to marketing practitioner by offering ample networking opportunities and contacts with executives and companies.

column1: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the marketing domain. Key questions that will be addressed during this course are: “What is marketing and the marketing concept?” and “How do companies create value?” Each session will consist of a blend of lecturing and (case) discussions. Students are expected to come well-prepared to classes and actively participate in the discussions.

As said, the course will be taught via a blend of (online) lectures and (case) discussions. During the lectures, concepts, frameworks, and theories will be presented and discussed, using practical examples to illustrate the ideas and highlight application and implementational issues.

Marketing management is not a “hard science”. There are, however, a number of theories and concepts that you need to master in order to understand and manage marketing. You will be asked to demonstrate your competences in an exam that consists of a series of open/ essay type questions. The exam will be “open-book” and will cover all the materials that have been discussed during lectures and made available through Canvas. Furthermore, all course readings (these will be made available through the university library before the course starts) will be exam material as well. Please check SIN Online for the exact timing of the exam and the resit.
The minimum grade requirement is 5.5. Please check the Examination Regulations page so that you are aware of the rules and regulations at RSM and for the MiM programme.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The primary objective of this course is for you to develop an in-depth understanding of the frameworks, concepts, models, and paradigms that collectively form the foundation for (strategic) marketing. Secondary objectives include developing skills in the application of this knowledge through analyzing and creating solutions for and approaches to marketing and business problems. Finally, the course should make you familiar with academic research in marketing (science).
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95870,2020,Marketing Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Genevsky'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Marketing strategy is a complex business function that requires a balance of analytical and synthetic skills. This course introduces a series of frameworks and tools that can be used to a) solve general business problems and b) develop specific marketing strategies and programs.

The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three Cs (customers, company, and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s), and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four Ps (product offering, pricing, promotion, and physical distribution).

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand how marketing is a force for positive change by creating long-term value for customers, companies and society in general.
• Understand why and how marketing is a central part of an organizational strategy by seeking to create superior value
• Understand that organizations need to identify and monitor the relevant stakeholders, macro and micro environmental factors/trends to spot and create novel opportunities for value creation
• Develop a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles and practices in strategic marketing
• Develop a thorough understanding of the core tactical elements of marketing management
• Understand and identify consumer motivations, needs and decision journeys
• Identify concrete real-world examples illustrating marketing theory and identify organizational problems as being marketing problems
• Ability to develop and communicate a coherent marketing plan
• Ability to analyze a complex business case with a small group of colleagues
• The use of several analytical tools, including tools used in targeting, brand management and pricing
• The ability to discuss complex business cases in a large group setting

column1: In today’s world oversupplied with media and entertainment content, the task of marketing movies, TV shows & channels, music, video games and comparable products is increasingly challenging. In a highly competitive environment, go-to-market strategies determine the product’s success or failure. In this course fundamental theories and perspectives on how entertainment is being marketed today are addressed.  Why and how is marketing media and entertainment products different to marketing products from any other sector? How is targeting fans different from reaching “traditional” target groups? These are central questions in the course. Furthermore, course topics include ‘positioning an entertainment property as a brand’, ‘building creative brand-centric strategies’, ‘creating products’ synergies’, ‘ecosystems and partnerships’, and ‘understanding how the digital world has impacted marketing and distribution’. The course allows students not only gain theoretical knowledge about the key aspects of leading strategic approaches, but also to learn how to translate them into actionable plans.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Marketing is the interface between a firm and its environment. It is the managerial practices that ensure customer-oriented managerial actions, including product design, pricing, market communication and product distribution, generate value for “customers”. The basic tenet is that managers should be able to justify that intended value-creation actions lead to sufficient customer responses such that they surpass the costs of these actions. However, in practice, achieving such goal is challenging, because of the sheer number of uncontrollable factors that influence customer responses. To address these challenges, academics and practitioners have developed and adopted a selection of analytical tools in the form of “marketing models”, which are crystallized from disciplines such as economics, statistics and computer science.

This course focuses on 1) how to translate managerial problems into analytical problems, and 2) how to solve these analytical problems with marketing models. In paricular, the course covers important marketing problems, such as how to successfully design and diffuse a new product, how to price a product or service to gain short-term profits and long-term equity, and how to build and manage heterogeneous and dynamic customer portfolios. The course adopts a hands-on approach, where you are expected to work on cases with actual data to solve real managerial problems. Overall, the course will show you how to understand, predict and influence customers using marketing models.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1    To explain the principles of marketing modeling with real-world examples.
2    To implement core marketing models (brand choice and demand models, customer segmentation, conjoint analysis, new product diffusion, and pricing) to solve managerial problems.
3    To differentiate the three basic functions of marketing models (i.e., prediction, evaluation and optimization).
4    To critically evaluate various marketing models, especially those new solutions.
5    To translate managerial problems into analytical problems, which can be solved by marketing models.
6    To develop solutions to managerial problems based on marketing models.

column1: Individuals or households can choose to respond or not to a direct mailing, or they can choose between various brands in the supermarket. This course deals with econometric models for these qualitative variables. Examples of these models are the logit and probit models for binomial data and multinomial logit models for multinomial data. Also, ordered data, like those evolving from questionnaires, and count data will be considered.
The focus of the course is on model representation, model interpretation, parameter estimation and diagnostics.</body>

• The students learns how to use econometric techniques (parameter estimation, diagnostic checking and forecasting) to construct a sound econometric model.
• The students learns how to interpret model parameters and translate estimation results into economic relevant information.

column1: The emphasis on this course is to use marketing research to aid to managerial decision making. Hence, we will focus our attention on the interpretation of statistical results in the applied aspects of various research techniques unique to marketing data. This is not a course on statistics and hence no attempt will be made to prove statistical theorems or derive mathematical solutions to statistical problems. However, this course builds heavily on prior knowledge on statistical methods and extends this to methods that are frequently used in marketing research. In particular, we will focus on ANOVA, linear regression models, choice models and factor analysis.

•          Apply statistical methods to real-life datasets with the help of SPSS.
•          Interpret the statistical output of your analyses.
•          Recommend marketing actions based on your interpretation of the results.</body>

column1: Instructors: Prof. F. Sotgiu (VU) and Prof. J. Guyt (UvA)

This course offers an overview of the econometric, statistical and behavioral foundations in the field of marketing science. It covers several substantive topics and discusses state-of-the-art methods that academic and industry marketers can use to make sense of ubiquitous market and consumer-level data (big data), as well as several state-of-the-art techniques for primary data collection (thick data).

This course introduces students to the field of marketing science which serves all those professionals – academics or practitioners – who answer important research questions in marketing using mathematical modeling. As such, marketing science draws upon solid econometric and statistical foundations that are common to other business data sciences. For example, we will discuss state-of-the-art econometric models and predictive analytics that firms can use to better understand their customers and optimize their marketing decisions.

Marketing science goes beyond purely predictive models with the goal of understanding customer and firm behavior. Students will find that this emphasis on cause-and-effect makes the field exciting and inherently interdisciplinary. For instance, we will be discussing how to draw upon theories from different fields (e.g., marketing, economics, psychology, and sociology) to build better mathematical models capable of generating more valuable customer and market insights.

Another related distinction between marketing science and other data sciences fields is that it goes beyond big data (i.e., data with high volume, velocity and variety) and also emphasizes thick data (i.e., in-depth data about customer and firm behavior, typically gathered through experiments, surveys or even qualitative methods), as well as the combination of both. Hence, in marketing science the ability to design and interpret primary research is a must. We will be discussing how to design, gather and use primary data to complement and enrich insights garnered through secondary data. Following these topics, students will familiarize themselves with (amongst others):
1. The use of aggregate level methods to quantify the market responses to marketing mix changes
2. Introduction into individual level choice models to measure consumer responses to marketing mix changes
3. The use of machine learning in market response models
4. Individual level choice model with Bayesian model of consumer learning and knowledge generalization
5. The use customer response and choice models in multichannel setting with timedimension and multiple touchpoints/customer contact mediums (Panel Probit and Logit)
6. Model based customer segmentation: Latent Class Clustering and Regression models

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After following this course students will have a deep understanding of the marketing science field, how it contributes to the generation of customer and market insights, as well as how they may possibly contribute to the field. Furthermore, students will be able to use theories from different disciplines, as well as primary data collection, to make better causal inferences and better predictions about customers and markets. Exposure to several interdisciplinary topics will also help students develop their creative skills and apply them in their own research, even if outside marketing science.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of marketing strategy is to develop and deploy an organization’s resources in the way that creates the most value for customers and other stakeholders. This course will help you to develop an in-depth understanding of key frameworks, concepts, and paradigms in marketing strategy and, just as important, to develop skills in the application of this knowledge. We will focus on two strategic problems, competitive positioning and innovation, and on two substantive areas, sustainability and technology. At a general level, the basic goal of this course is to help you make the transition from student to marketing practitioner and thus support your own goal of becoming a successful marketing professional. During the course, you will train extensively your case solving skills both in class, during interactive case discussions, and individually, in the assignments and trial exams. Student participation during the interactive lectures and meaningful contributions to the case discussions are essential. To facilitate interaction, the group will be split into three sections for some of the classes. Students will be tested by means of an exam and written case assignments (both individual and group).

Understand how companies can become more innovative
Recognize potential ethical issues in marketing practice

column1: Overall, the course intends to make you well-informed and critical users of quantitative marketing, by presenting the essential tools and processes that are needed to make data-driven decisions for marketing strategies. Specifically, this course introduces a set of quantitative marketing tools that are essential for marketing strategy research. Through the discussion and application of these tools, the course intends to develop your abilities to identify and apply the right methods to solve marketing strategy problems. During the course, you will be offered hands-on training in marketing analytics with real datasets. Moreover, with case discussion, you will learn how to identify opportunities to improve business performances with marketing analytics (i.e., “when to use”), and formulate unbiased understanding of analytical tools (i.e., “how to choose”).

column1: Many healthcare organizations are undergoing tremendous challenges at a fast pace. Main reasons are an increasing number of older people and people getting older (the ‘Grey market’), tightened budgets, and consumer empowerment. Effective marketing strategy is essential for any profit and nonprofit organization to stay competitive across all industries, including the healthcare industry with its many players. Some of the key producers and providers of goods and services of the healthcare industry are for instance the pharmaceutical and biotechnology firms, nursing / elderly homes and hospitals. The pharmaceutical industry will be one the players addressed in more detail during the course.
The main goal of this course is to introduce students to a variety of topics with marketing (strategy) and customer-centric thinking as key themes.
Some of the topics that the lectures will cover include:
1. Trends and challenges of the industry
2. What is marketing strategy and customer-centered thinking in healthcare?
3. Marketing strategy and the pharmaceutical sector
Check the video for more information:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In het huidige economische klimaat leidt de sterk toegenomen concurrentie ertoe dat veel bedrijven het moeilijk hebben om te overleven. Ondanks deze onzekere tijden, zijn er enkele bedrijven die er keer op keer in slagen om succesvolle producten te lanceren en hun marktaandeel op systematische wijze te vergroten. Dit doet natuurlijk de volgende vraag rijzen: welke factoren zorgen ervoor dat het ene bedrijf succesvoller is dan het andere? In het vak Marketing Management bekijken we een van de belangrijkste redenen: veel van deze succesvolle bedrijven handelen namelijk vanuit een strategisch marketingperspectief. Door op systematische wijze in te spelen op de behoeften van klanten, presenteren zij een klantgericht producten- en dienstenaanbod dat duidelijk te onderscheiden is van de concurrentie.

In plaats van marketing louter te bekijken als de verkoop van bestaande producten en diensten, benadrukt dit vak hoe marketing management veelal een geïntegreerde strategie is waarbij de behoeften van de klant centraal staan. Daarvoor bekijken we hoe bedrijven de uiteenlopende behoeften van de klant kunnen analyseren en hoe ze op basis hiervan een strategie kunnen ontwikkelen waardoor ze zich kunnen onderscheiden van de concurrentie. Hierbij is het niet alleen van belang om goed uitgekiende producten en diensten te ontwikkelen, maar ook om doordachte beslissingen te nemen met betrekking tot distributiekanalen, prijs en promotiecampagnes.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na het met succes volgen van dit vak:

column2: • Na het met succes volgen van dit vak:

• Bent u in staat om te begrijpen en argumenteren hoe marketing een centraal deel is van de organisatiestrategie en hoe marketing een “force for positive change” kan zijn door het creëren van lange-termijn waarde voor klanten, bedrijven en de maatschappij in het algemeen;
• Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de fundamentele principes binnen strategische marketing;
• Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de centrale tactische elementen van marketing management;
• Bent u in staat om voorbeelden te geven van de gangbare onderzoeksmethoden in marketing management;
• Bent u in staat om te consumentenmotivaties, behoeften en beslissingsroutes te identificeren en te begrijpen;

• Bent u in staat om voorbeelden die illustratief zijn van marketing theorie of duiden op problemen met een marketingstrategie te identificeren, en aanbevelingen te maken op basis van relevante literatuur.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the marketing domain. Key questions that will be addressed during this course are: “What is marketing and the marketing concept?” and “How do companies develop a competitive advantage according to the marketing concept?” and “How is marketing affected by the use of social media?” Each session will consist of a blend of lecturing and (case) discussions. Students are expected to come well-prepared to classes and actively participate in the discussions.

During the lectures, concepts, frameworks, and theories will be presented and discussed, using practical examples to illustrate the ideas and highlight implementation issues as they are relevant for managers.

During the case discussions, you will be expected to analyse realistic problem situations in the form of business cases. While developing solutions, you will make use of core concepts in marketing and you will learn to apply them to a concrete case. As in actual practice, cases are characterized by a limited time frame for making decisions, incomplete information, and no clear ""best"" answer. The case method is essential to developing the kind of problem-solving and communication skills highly valued in the managerial practice. The ability to generalize from the specific case situations discussed in class to new situations that you may encounter is one of the foundations of management education.

During case discussions, a poorly prepared class invariably leads to an unrewarding experience for all involved. Thus, the long-term benefits from this course will be proportional to the extent that you make this course your project. This means that you are expected to come to class prepared and to actively participate. Specifically, you are expected to contribute to an informed exchange about the topic of the class and to have well-developed points of view about the cases and other reading material.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The primary objective of this course is for you to develop an in-depth understanding of the frameworks, concepts, models, and paradigms that collectively form the foundation for (strategic) marketing management. Secondary objectives include developing skills in the application of this knowledge for making decisions at the business level and developing an appreciation for the inter-disciplinary nature of marketing strategy.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: New products, which are also called innovations, provide new ways to create value for customers, and moreover, it yields growth and profitability for firms. A huge percentage of a company’s sales and profit is generally earned by products that have been launched in the past five years. However, at the same time, many new products fail, and disappear from the market sooner or later after its launch. This is very problematic for companies, given the huge amount of money involved in the research and development of new products. The success or failure of a new product is determined by its ultimate acceptance in the market place. This raises the question which factors influence the acceptance and diffusion of new products in the market place? This question will be central in this course. The answer to this question provides marketing managers with information on how to effectively develop and launch new products.

During this course the students get acquainted with both conceptual and tacit knowledge of important methods in launching new products, and moreover in tracking the new product launch. Additionally, this course will provide a structured overview of the body of knowledge on adoption and diffusion of new products in the market place, and moreover, insights into how this knowledge can be incorporated in new product launch decisions. Attention will be paid to the consumer adoption decision process as well as to the new product adoption decisions by retailers, both in the domestic and the international market. The course challenges you to think critically about new products marketing. As such, routine learning of terms and concepts is not sufficient. You are prepared to take a marketing manager’s seat in managing new products across international markets.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The learning objectives of the course are:
1.    To be able to develop an optimal launch strategy.
2.    To gain insights into the retailers’ adoption decision process.
3.    To gain insights in the consumers’ adoption process.
4.    To gain insights in the new product diffusion process.
5.    To be able to forecast the success of a new product.

column1: This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

column1: <body>The master’s thesis is the major project in the entire programme. With their master's thesis, students demonstrate that they are able to contribute to academic and sophisticated professional debates on a specific subject. Each student that achieved satisfactory results in his/her coursework will be appointed with a supervisor. Supervisors will provide personal advice on various occasions to ensure that students can make reliable progress. The master's thesis will fulfil the following criteria:

column2: • it is based on a clearly formulated research question;
• it relates to theories and methodologies of the discipline, or theories and methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
• the selected theories and methodologies are discussed and justified in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme are summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to the original aspects of the thesis;
• the academic literature as well as all other information and data used are systematically presented and related to the main theme of the thesis;
• the thesis contains a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
• the thesis contains an introduction, various chapters in which theory, method and the findings are discussed, a conclusion, a bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
• the literature, sources and other information and data are accurately referenced;
• the thesis is written in polished, accurate English;
• the main text of the thesis does not far exceed 20.000 words.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Writing a master's thesis is the central feature of the research master's programme. The master's thesis enables students, based on their own original research, to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to the academic debate of a specific subject in their field of study. The following are additional requirements that the master's thesis must satisfy:

column2: • the research will based on a clearly formulated problem and subsequent research questions;
• the research will be based on theories and methodologies relevant to the field of study and the specific theme;
• the theories and methodologies will be discussed and argued in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme will be indicated, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research;
• the literature used, primary and secondary sources, other information and data will be systematically presented and interrelated;
• the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion.

column1: The master's thesis should have the format of an article for an international peer-reviewed academic journal. As such it should meet the following requirements:

column2: • the article will contain a clearly stated research problem and research question(s); a description of the scientific/ background and relevance of the research question(s); an outline of the methods of data collection and analysis; a presentation and discussion of the findings, and a conclusion highlighting the scientific relevance of the findings and how these relate to the existent literature on the topic;
• the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and the references, and, if necessary, in separate appendices;
• the article will be preceded by an abstract (200-400 words) and five key words;
• the article accords with the established formats of the relevant journal(s) within the disciplinary and thematic field that fits the research topic.
• the article will be written in polished, accurate English;
• the article will consist of a maximum of 10.000 words, excluding footnotes and references, tables and figures, abstract and key words.

• Report on the results/findings in a coherent and reflexive way
• Evaluate the conclusions and choices made during the research process
• Write an academic article in English, to be submitted for publication to an international peer-reviewed academic journal

column1: In this course, students decide on the topic and shape the outlines of their Master Thesis – an original and autonomously conducted academic study. Throughout, the emphasis is on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a  well-structured research design. During the ‘thesis market’ the available supervisors of the programme will suggest themes and topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers, but may also consist of questions/requests for research that specific cultural organisations might have. After that, students will come up with a topic of their interest. They will then develop this into a suitable, feasible and well-argued research proposal, which will be the basis of the work on the actual Master Thesis.

This course consists of two components. On the one hand, there is a personal trajectory in which students will develop a plan for their Master Thesis in the form of a research proposal. They will do so through consecutive assignments, where there is room for trial-and-error and individual feedback is provided in the various steps. On the other hand, regular meetings serve as collective checkpoints to streamline the process. In doing so, ample attention is paid to content-related matters and designing a suitable method, as well as the time planning and formal criteria, to make sure that the Master Thesis (and the Master Thesis proposal) is in line with the programme’s requirements. Therefore, we will consider (and in some cases freshen up) topics such as conceptualizing, searching for and integrating literature, various methodologies, and academic writing.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, including an introduction (research question and relevance), a literature review/theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will identify a topic, formulate a clear research question, search for, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable method of research.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92101,2020,Master Thesis Class,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

First, we will explain all the content-related and formal criteria the Master Thesis and master thesis proposal have to fulfil as well as the time planning. Second, during the ‘thesis market’ the lecturers of the programme will present potential thesis topics which lie on the intersections between place, culture and tourism that students can – but do not have to – choose as their Master Thesis topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers or consist of questions specific cultural organisations might have. Third, we will elaborate on turning a relevant and feasible topic into a research question. During the last two meetings, students will start writing their master thesis proposal. Fourth, students learn to search, find and select relevant literature and make efficient use of various digital search tools. The emphasis, however, will be on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a well-structured and logical research design.  Fifth, students will receive tips and tricks and practice their writing skills and learn to monitor and optimize the writing process.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, focusing on the intertwined relationship between place, culture and tourism. This includes an introduction (research question and relevance), a theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will be able to identify a topic, formulate a concise research question, search, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable methodology.

In order to complete the Master of HEPL, with specialisation Health Economics, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HEPL Master. The combined workload of the Thesis Plan and Thesis is 16 ECTS (or 448 hours) and thus constitutes a major part of the curriculum. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HEPL staff. The evaluation of the thesis and defence for the final grade is conducted by the student's thesis reading committee, which includes the supervisor and one co-evaluator. The co-evaluator must be someone from the ESHPM or ESE staff.
More information regarding the HE thesis, the graduation procedure, and a link to the coursebook can be found at https://www.eur.nl/ese/english/information_for/students/master_students/master_

column1: : This course has two main objectives, i.e.to train students in essential academic skills and to guide them towards their MA-thesis: Firstly, students get the opportunity to learn, train and improve a number of essential academic skills. They are introduced and trained in techniques of argumentation and reasoning. Essential basics of academic writing, such as citation techniques, are rehearsed and students are introduced to the skills of philosophical writing. Last but certainly not least, students get the opportunity to train and improve their presentation skills.

Secondly, students are guided towards their MA-thesis in a milestone-process. In this process they learn how to choose a suitable topic for their thesis before they proceed in specifying a tractable research question. In a next step, students are guided in further developing their question into a thesis outline. They present their outline to their peers in order to receive first feedback before embarking on the process of writing their thesis in block 4. </body>

column1: <body>During this course, students learn about the structure of a master thesis and about the available master thesis topics. Students obtain comprehensive guidance in an information and Q&A session before they select their topic. During and after the session, students can ask questions as well as ask for additional advice. After the orientation session, students select their master thesis topic from the topic list, read the recommended literature and independently prepare a draft of their research idea (max 3 pages), which has to be submitted to the coach. The research idea can be based either on the pre-defined questions indicated in the topic description or on own ideas within the indicated topics, depending on the capabilities, creativity and ambition of the individual students. During the meeting, the coach provides the student with feedback on the research idea, which students have to incorporate. Students have to hand in a document containing the introduction and literature review chapters of the thesis. Students pass this stage if this document is of sufficient quality.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After the course, students should be able to;
»        summarize the literature relevant to the chosen master thesis topic;
»        identify one or more gaps in the literature;
»        formulate research questions to address the identified gap(s) in the literature;
»        explain the contribution of the proposed research to the literature;
»        describe the academic and practical relevance of the proposed research;
»        identify the methods and data sources necessary to conduct the proposed research;
»        write an introduction and literature review containing all of the above elements.</body>

column1: The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master's specialisation. More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Master's thesis website.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which they can initiate and perform a literature review which is useful for their research project.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of accounting, auditing, control or finance can be applied to their own research topic.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the application of up-to-date qualitative or quantitative research methods.

• Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments as well as to formulate hypotheses in a systematic and valid way.

• Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

• Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which they can initiate and perform a literature review which is useful for their research project.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of marketing can be applied to their own research topic.

• Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments as well as to formulate hypotheses in a systematic and valid way.

• Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

• Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.
